title: Exile and Hope
shortSummary: Jeremiah 29 records a letter from the prophet Jeremiah to the Jewish exiles in Babylon, instructing them to live faithfully during their captivity and promising God's future restoration after seventy years. The chapter warns against false prophets and encourages seeking God wholeheartedly, emphasizing His sovereign plans for peace and redemption.
timeline: c. 597 BC - Babylonian Exile during the reign of King Jeconiah

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who sends a letter to the Jewish captives in Babylon, delivering God's instructions and promises.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadnezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon who carried the people of Judah into captivity.

keyCharacters.name: Shemaiah the Nehelamite
keyCharacters.description: A false prophet who opposed Jeremiah’s message and was condemned by God.

keyCharacters.name: Elasah son of Shaphan and Gemariah son of Hilkiah
keyCharacters.description: Messengers who delivered Jeremiah’s letter from Jerusalem to the exiles in Babylon.

definitions.definition: Jews taken from Jerusalem and Judah into exile in Babylon as a result of God's judgment.
A person called by God to deliver His messages, often including warnings and promises.
Individuals who claim to speak for God but deliver deceptive or incorrect messages.
God’s promised future hope and restoration for His people after a period of judgment.

outline.heading: Introduction and Letter Sent to the Exiles
outline.description: Jeremiah sends a letter through trusted messengers to the Jewish elders, priests, prophets, and people exiled in Babylon, conveying God’s message to them.

outline.heading: Instructions for Life in Exile
outline.description: God commands the exiles to build homes, plant gardens, marry, and seek the welfare of Babylon, promising peace to those who pray for the city.

outline.heading: Warning Against False Prophets
outline.description: God warns the exiles not to listen to false prophets who claim to speak in His name but deceive the people with lies.

outline.heading: Promise of Restoration After Seventy Years
outline.description: God declares that after seventy years in Babylon, He will bring His people back to Jerusalem, promising peace and a hopeful future for those who seek Him sincerely.

outline.heading: Judgment on Jerusalem and False Prophets
outline.description: God pronounces judgment on those remaining in Jerusalem for their disobedience and condemns false prophets like Shemaiah who mislead the people, affirming His sovereign justice.

application: Trust God’s sovereign plan even in difficult circumstances, knowing He works all things for His people’s ultimate good.
Live faithfully and seek the welfare of your community, praying for peace and blessing even when in challenging environments.
Discern and reject false teachings by grounding yourself in God’s Word and seeking Him with all your heart.
Hold on to God’s promises of restoration and hope, maintaining a prayerful and repentant heart.

keyVerses.text: For I know the thoughts that I think toward you, saith the LORD, thoughts of peace, and not of evil, to give you an expected end.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reassures believers of God’s good intentions and hopeful plans for their future.

keyVerses.text: And seek the peace of the city whither I have caused you to be carried away captives, and pray unto the LORD for it: for in the peace thereof shall ye have peace.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches believers to pray for and seek the welfare of their communities, even in exile.

keyVerses.text: And ye shall seek me, and find me, when ye shall search for me with all your heart.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the promise that God will reveal Himself to those who earnestly seek Him.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the LORD, That after seventy years be accomplished at Babylon I will visit you, and perform my good word toward you, in causing you to return to this place.
keyVerses.significance: It confirms God’s faithfulness to fulfill His promises of restoration after a set period of discipline.
